Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrating Research and Education via Low-Temperature Solventless Formation of Hierarchical Porous-on-Porous Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding for the development of a new technique to deposit functional porous polymers onto porous materials in order to develop microfluidic devices for disease detection and multifunctional filtration membranes for water purification. The primary objective of this research is to determine the mechanism and kinetics associated with using significantly reduced substrate temperatures in order to simultaneously freeze and polymerize monomer, leading to the formation of novel porous-on-porous materials. The research approach is to systematically evaluate the effects of process parameters on the pore size distribution, investigate the formation of both uncapped and capped membranes, determine whether localized cooling can control pore formation in the x, y, and z-directions, and utilize the new-found implications of controlling the symmetry, surface chemistry, and structure of these membranes to create innovative, real-world multifunctional porous-on-porous materials.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a fundamental understanding of the chemistry and physics associated with low-temperature deposition of polymer membranes, and ultimately the fabrication of next-generation diagnostic devices and purification membranes. A series of hands-on demonstrations will be developed to ignite interest in engineering fields among middle school students in downtown Los Angeles that rarely have access to such topics. A new multi-tiered mentorship program will be created by pairing female students with female faculty in order to foster career development and help improve the retention of women in engineering fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study a new process to fabricate functional polymer membranes. Polymer membranes are useful for a wide range of real-world applications including water filtration and medical diagnostic assays. Our fabrication method does not use any solvents and therefore is more environmentally-friendly compared to traditional liquid phase processes. We systematically studied the morphology of the pores and the molecular weight of the polymer chains. Our results showed that we could control the thickness, molecular weight, and porosity of the porous polymer membranes by varying process parameters such as temperature and deposition time. We showed that we can coat curved surfaces and planar surfaces and we could pattern the location of growth using physical masks. Asymmetric membranes are important for many practical separation applications. We designed a new process to fabricate asymmetric membranes by depositing a dense layer first and then subsequently depositing a porous layer, resulting in membranes that are fully hydrophilic, fully hydrophobic, or asymmetric in both structure and chemical functionality. Our studies show the versatility and capabilities of our process. We published seven peer-reviewed papers and received one patent for this work. Our results were presented at other universities and at national conferences. Our results will allow future scientists and engineers to fabricate a wide range of functional polymer membranes for a variety of applications. The major educational outcomes of this project were the training of several graduate students, the development of hands-on toolkits for fabricating microfluidic channels, and the mentorship of female undergraduate and graduate students in engineering.


Last Modified: 05/01/2019
Modified by: Malancha Gupta

Polymer membranes are useful for a wide range of real-world applications including water filtration and medical diagnostic assays. Our fabrication method does not use any solvents and therefore is more environmentally-friendly compared to traditional liquid phase processes. Our results showed that we could control the thickness, molecular weight, and porosity of the porous polymer membranes by varying process parameters such as temperature and deposition time. We showed that we can coat curved surfaces and planar surfaces and we could pattern the location of growth using physical masks. Asymmetric membranes are important for many practical separation applications. Our studies show the versatility and capabilities of our process. We published seven peer-reviewed papers and received one patent for this work. Our results will allow future scientists and engineers to fabricate a wide range of functional polymer membranes for a variety of applications.
